title: Shawford to Winchester Walk Route

images.title: Geoff Barker / Itchen Navigation at Shawford, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Itchen Navigation at Shawford. This canal runs from Southampton to Winchester through the river Itchen valley. It closed as a commercial entity in 1869.

images.title: Peter Facey / Railway bridge at Bridge Terrace, Shawford, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Railway bridge at Bridge Terrace, Shawford. Looking WNW. Bridge Terrace is on right. Behind photographer is the River Itchen and the Itchen Way.

images.title: Jim Champion / Weir at Shawford Mill, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Weir at Shawford Mill. This sluice and weir was once part of the workings of Shawford Mill on the Itchen Navigation.

images.title: Steve Rigg / Bridge over river Itchen, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Bridge over river Itchen. This bridge over the river Itchen, between Shawford and Twyford, has a stone inscribed with 1750

images.title: Peter Trimming / The Itchen Navigation, Winchester, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: The Itchen Navigation, Winchester A section of disused canal navigation, south of Winchester. Photograph taken from The Itchen Way, which runs from Winchester to Portsmouth.

images.title: Peter Trimming / Along the Itchen Navigation, Winchester, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Along the Itchen Navigation, Winchester Looking towards the city centre, along a stretch of disused canal navigation.

description: Enjoy a nice riverside walk from Shawford to Winchester on this easy route in Hampshire. It's about a 3 mile walk using a series of good surfaced paths along the River Itchen and the Itchen Navigation. You can return on the same paths or catch the train back from Winchester if you prefer. The walk starts from Shawford train station and follows the waymarked Itchen Way north along the River Itchen. You'll pass Hockley Golf Course and the noteworthy St Catherine's Hill . You could take a small detour from the route and enjoy fine views over Winchester from the summit.  It's a very pretty area with the chalk downland covered in wild flowers including bird's-foot trefoil, salad burnet, dropwort and several types of orchid. Soon after passing the hill the route enters the outskirts of Winchester before finishing at the famous cathedral.
